intro: Leptoceras macrophylla, commonly known as the large-leafed woodruff, is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is native to parts of Southeast Asia. It is characterized by its broad, heart-shaped leaves that can reach up to 15 centimeters in length. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers that are clustered in umbels, often blooming in the spring. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forest understories and is often found in tropical and subtropical regions. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation areas.
